dev_note: The request to add "changed" hints to the translation settings page suggests a need for improved discoverability of modifications. A semantic HTML approach should be prioritized. Consider using `<details>` and `<summary>` elements to group and reveal changes.  Within the `<summary>`, clearly articulate what has been changed, for example:  `<summary>Translation Settings - Changes Made</summary>  [Content of the settings page].  Alternatively, if the page utilizes interactive elements (e.g., toggles, dropdowns) that have been altered, use ARIA attributes like `aria-expanded` on the `<summary>` element to reflect the expanded/collapsed state and `aria-describedby` to link to a descriptive text explaining the change. Avoid using ARIA solely to indicate a change; focus on making the change itself understandable.  Ensure sufficient color contrast for any accompanying text.  The goal is to allow screen reader users to immediately identify what has been updated without needing to navigate extensively or rely on purely visual cues.

Issue Title: META: Support HTML5 form input elements
Description: META: Support HTML5 form input elements
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty interacting with form elements if the HTML5 input types are not correctly interpreted and announced. This can lead to a reduced understanding of the form's purpose and fields, hindering accurate completion.
dev_note: The issue title, "META: Support HTML5 form input elements," is a very high-level request. The core problem is the *implementation* of HTML5 form input types, not the META tag itself.  It’s assumed the system is attempting to correctly leverage the semantic meaning of the HTML5 input types (e.g., `type="email"` automatically provides a hint for email input). To ensure accessibility, developers should: 1. Verify that the HTML5 input types are being correctly interpreted by the assistive technology stack (screen readers). 2. Ensure the semantic HTML structure is correctly applied to the form. For example, use `<label>` elements associated with each input field, ensuring the `for` attribute correctly matches the input's `id`. 3.  If the screen reader isn't announcing the correct input type hint (e.g., "email" for `<input type="email">`), investigate the assistive technology configuration or potential issues with the screen reader.  ARIA is generally not needed for this scenario; prioritize correct semantic HTML.  Check for any custom CSS that might be interfering with the screen reader’s ability to announce the input type.

Issue Title: After enabling or disabling a view, convey changes to screen reader users.
Description: After enabling or disabling a view, convey changes to screen reader users.
acr_note: Screen reader users may be unable to determine if a view has been successfully toggled, leading to confusion and difficulty navigating the interface. This represents a barrier to understanding the current state of the application and may prevent users with disabilities from completing tasks.
dev_note: This issue highlights the need for explicit and perceptible feedback when a user changes a view state. The primary solution should be to utilize semantic HTML elements to represent the view state change. For example, if a “dark mode” view is toggled, use `<input type="checkbox">` with a `<label>` to control the state and a clear visual indicator (e.g., a toggle switch) that updates immediately upon state change.  ARIA roles are only needed to supplement semantic HTML if necessary. If a native solution isn't possible, use `role="button"` on the toggle element and provide appropriate `aria-expanded` and `aria-checked` attributes to indicate its state.  Ensure the toggle state is announced by the screen reader when the focus shifts to it. Avoid relying solely on color changes for conveying state, as this can be problematic for users with color blindness. Prioritize clear and consistent messaging.

Issue Title: Dropbutton should report open/closed state to assistive technology

acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to determine the current state of a Dropbutton (open or closed) without additional assistive technology support. This lack of clear state information can impede navigation and interaction, creating a barrier to usability.

Issue Title: Make the show/hide row weights button more informative for assistive tech users.
Description: Make the show/hide row weights button more informative for assistive tech users.
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may not receive sufficient information about the purpose and state of the "show/hide row weights" button, potentially leading to confusion and difficulty in managing the display of row weights. dev_note: The issue suggests a lack of clear communication about the button’s function to assistive technology users. The primary solution is to utilize semantic HTML to convey this information. Issue Title: Status Message in Claro on theme install should have role="status" or similar instead of contentinfo
Description: Status Message in Claro on theme install should have role="status" or similar instead of contentinfo
acr_note: The status message displayed during Claro theme installation may not be clearly perceivable by users of assistive technologies. Currently using `contentinfo` semantics does not adequately convey the purpose of the message to screen reader users, potentially leading to confusion about the installation process's progress.
dev_note: The issue identifies a semantic mismatch in the HTML structure of the status message. `contentinfo` is intended for informational text that doesn't directly relate to interactive elements.  The status message during theme installation *is* an indicator of progress and should be treated as such.
